questions.text: A 30-year-old male suffers from a road traffic accident, and a car runs over his right leg. On examination, vitals are stable. The right leg is crushed with exposed muscles and bones. The debate about limb survival can be resolved to an extent by the MESS score, which includes all except:
questions.solution:
Explanation:

The Mangled Extremity Severity Score (MESS) is a validated clinical tool used to determine whether a severely injured limb should be salvaged or amputated. The score includes four components, none of which are "Velocity of trauma."

Mangled Extremity Severity Score (MESS Score):

  • This score is used to predict the chances of amputation after severe extremity trauma. In cases of massive crushing of a limb, this score helps to predict whether to go for limb salvage or to empirically amputate the limb to save the life of the patient.
  • It consists of four variables, and the final score is the sum of all four variables:
    1. Skeletal and soft tissue injury (graded 1-4)
    2. Ischemia of limb (graded 1-3, score is doubled for ischemia of more than 6 hours)
    3. Shock (graded 0-2)
    4. Age (graded 0-2).
    5. A score of 7 or more is highly predictive of amputation. It is highly specific, but less sensitive in predicting the fate of an injured limb.

Explanation of Other Options:

Shock (Option A): Component of MESS; scored 0-2 depending on systolic BP.

Soft tissue injury (Option B): Major component; graded 1-4.

Distal circulation (Option D): Considered under ischemia/perfusion; part of MESS scoring.

questions.text: A lady presented in the emergency department with a history of trauma to the neck region. Identify the shown fracture in the image.
questions.solution:
Explanation:

The shown image is a case of atlanto-axial dislocation

  • Atlantoaxial dislocation commonly presents with fracture, as compared to pure dislocation of C1 (Atlas) and C2 (Axis)
  • Pure dislocation is commonly associated with neurological deficit
  • MC type of atlanto-axial dislocation: Anterior
  • Treatment: Skull traction followed by immobilisation using the Minerva jacket.
  • Hangman fracture: Fracture through the pedicle and lamina of C2 vertebra, with subluxation of C2 over C3. This type of fracture is seen in judicial hangings.
  • Jefferson fracture: Fracture of the C1 vertebra
  • Clay-shoveler fracture: Avulsion fracture of the spinous process of one or more of the lower cervical or upper thoracic vertebrae. The name is given as it is caused by muscular action in shovelling by labourers.

Explanation of Other Options:

Jefferson fracture (Option B): Burst fracture of the C1 (atlas) involving anterior and posterior arches; results from axial loading (e.g. diving injury); diagnosed on open-mouth odontoid view.

Hangman fracture (Option C): Fracture of the pars interarticularis of C2 (axis) due to hyperextension injury; subluxation of C2 over C3 may be seen.

Clay-shoveler fracture (Option D): Avulsion fracture of the spinous process of C6, C7, or T1; caused by sudden muscular contraction; typically stable and not associated with neurologic deficits.

Key Takeaways:

questions.text: A 25-year-old man presents with a gunshot injury to his right thigh. There is an entry wound of 1cm and no exit wound. He has also sustained a comminuted fracture of the distal femur and a Popliteal artery injury. What is the grade according to the Anderson-Gustilo classification?
questions.solution:
Explanation:

If there is an arterial injury that needs to be repaired, regardless of the amount of other soft tissue damage, it is considered grade IIIC.

  • Gunshot wounds are typically considered Grade III, and if they involve vascular injury requiring repair, it is classified as Grade IIIC.
  • Early vascular repair and skeletal stabilisation are priorities in such injuries.
  • These cases carry a high risk of infection, compartment syndrome, and limb loss, necessitating multidisciplinary management.

Explanation of Other Options:

Grade 1 (Option A): Applies to low-energy injuries with <1 cm wound and no vascular involvement.

Grade 2 (Option B): Moderate soft tissue damage with a wound 1-10 cm, but no arterial injury or bone exposure.

Grade 3A (Option C): Large wounds with extensive soft tissue damage but intact vascular supply and soft tissue coverage possible.

Key Takeaways:

  • Any vascular injury needing repair → Grade 3C (irrespective of wound size).
  • Gunshot wounds with comminution usually ≥ Grade 3A.
  • Early identification of vascular compromise is critical in limb salvage decisions.

questions.text: What is the treatment of Anderson-Gustilo classification grade 3B?
questions.solution:
Explanation:

Grade 3B injuries involve extensive soft tissue loss with periosteal stripping and bone exposure; if early debridement and wound control are possible, antibiotic-coated intramedullary nailing is a viable internal fixation strategy.

Gustilo-Anderson Grade 3B Management:

  • Definition:
    • High-energy injury with extensive soft tissue damage
    • Periosteal stripping and exposed bone
    • Requires soft tissue reconstruction (e.g. local or free flap)
  • Standard treatment:
    • Initial debridement
    • External fixation is typically preferred in contaminated or unstable settings
    • In select early-presenting cases, antibiotic-coated intramedullary nailing may be used if wound contamination is minimal and closure is achievable
  • Antibiotic-coated nails:
    • Deliver high local antibiotic concentration
    • Provide early stabilisation and allow earlier soft tissue healing

Explanation of Other Options:

Intramedullary wiring (Option B): Obsolete method, not suitable for high-grade open fractures or bone exposure.

Closed reduction (Option C): Contraindicated in open fractures; surgical debridement is mandatory.

K-wire (Option D): Insufficient for stabilising major long bone fractures and not used in Grade 3B injuries.

Key Takeaways:

  • Grade 3B requires aggressive debridement and stabilisation.
  • External fixation is commonly used initially.
  • Antibiotic-coated intramedullary nailing is an acceptable alternative in clean wounds with early presentation.

questions.text: A 24-year-old female army cadet presents with gradually increasing pain over the dorsum of her right foot for the past 2 weeks. She reports recent long marches and intensified training drills. There is localised tenderness over the midfoot and mild swelling. The X-ray shows no obvious fracture. What is the most likely site of a stress fracture?
questions.solution:
Explanation:

Metatarsals, particularly the second and third, are the most frequent sites of stress fractures, especially in military recruits and athletes undergoing repetitive loading.

Stress Fractures:

  • Definition: Fatigue fractures caused by repetitive submaximal loading on normal bone
  • Commonly affected population: Runners, dancers, army recruits
  • Most common sites:
    • Lower limb:
      • Tibia (lower third) - overall, most common
      • Metatarsals - especially 2nd > 3rd ("march fracture" in military)
    • Upper limb: Olecranon in throwing athletes
  • Clinical features:
    • Insidious onset of pain aggravated by activity, relieved by rest
    • Localised bony tenderness without significant trauma
  • Imaging:
    • Early X-rays may be normal
    • MRI: Investigation of choice for early diagnosis
    • Bone scan: Preferred in bilateral cases

Explanation of Other Options:

Metacarpals (Option B): Rarely affected due to less weight-bearing stress; not a typical site of stress fractures.

Calcaneum (Option C): Can be involved, but less common than metatarsals or tibia.

Talus (Option D): Occasional site, especially in jumpers, but not the most common.

Key Takeaways:

  • March fracture = stress fracture of the 2nd or 3rd metatarsal.
  • Tibia and metatarsals are the most frequently involved bones in stress fractures.
  • MRI is the investigation of choice in early or occult cases.

questions.text: A 28-year-old long-distance runner presents with lateral ankle pain that worsens after running and persists at rest. There is localised tenderness over the distal fibula with mild swelling. X-ray is inconclusive, but MRI reveals a cortical stress reaction in the distal fibula. What is the most likely diagnosis?
questions.solution:
Explanation:

A Runner's fracture is a stress fracture of the distal fibula, commonly seen in runners due to repetitive loading of the lateral compartment.

  • Runner's fracture refers to stress injury to the distal fibula in repetitive endurance activity (e.g., marathon running)
  • It results from cyclical stress and microtrauma due to repetitive strain
  • Presents with:
    • Gradual-onset lateral lower leg pain
    • Tenderness over the distal fibula
    • Often normal X-ray; MRI is more sensitive

Explanation of Other Options:

Tibial stress fracture (Option B): Most common stress fracture site, but presents with anterior leg pain, not lateral.

Calcaneal stress fracture (Option C): Presents with heel pain, worsened by weight-bearing.

Metatarsal stress fracture (Option D): Common in runners but presents with forefoot pain, especially over the 2nd metatarsal.

Key Takeaways:

  • Runner's fracture = distal fibula stress fracture
  • MRI is preferred over X-ray for early detection
  • Always consider overuse stress injury in athletes with localised pain and a normal X-ray

questions.text: A 36-year-old female is brought to the emergency department with a history of RTA. She is unconscious and has swelling around her cervical spine. What is the first step in management?
questions.solution:
Explanation:

In trauma patients with suspected cervical spine injury, the first step is cervical spine immobilisation even before airway manoeuvres.

  • In any seriously injured patient, we must follow the ATLS protocol
  • Advanced trauma life support (ATLS) is a periodically updated, evidence-based training course for physicians and surgeons who are involved in the care of trauma patients. The concept behind ATLS is to save a life by addressing the most dangerous threat to life first.
  • Patients are rapidly assessed on the basis of the 'ABCDE' resuscitation system.
    • Airway control with stabilisation of the cervical spine.
    • Breathing assessment - management of respiratory distress.
    • Circulation - assessment of shock and management of external haemorrhage.
    • Disability or neurological status management of head injury.
    • Exposure or undressing of the patient.
  • In this case, as the patient has swelling in the cervical spine, we presume an injury there. So, before doing any manoeuvres for securing the airway or intubating the patient, we must apply a Philadelphia collar. If we do not do that, we may aggravate a cervical spine injury and cause quadriparesis/ quadriplegia.

Explanation of Other Options:

GCS scoring (Option A): Important in disability assessment (D), but comes after airway and spine protection.

Mannitol (Option C): Used for suspected raised intracranial pressure, which is not the first step.

Airway maintenance (Option D): Vital, but must be done only after stabilising the cervical spine to prevent spinal cord injury.

Key Takeaways:

  • ATLS begins with GCS scoring, but spine protection precedes airway handling.
  • In trauma with suspected cervical injury, immobilise first, then secure the airway.
  • Always presume cervical spine fracture until ruled out clinically and radiologically.

choices.text: Green stick fracture of the lower end of the radius

questions.text: Which of the following is the most common fracture in children?
questions.solution:
Explanation:

Greenstick fracture of the distal radius is the most common type of fracture seen in children due to the pliable nature of their bones.

  • Greenstick fractures are incomplete fractures where the bone bends and cracks, instead of breaking completely into separate pieces.
  • These are typically seen in the distal radius, especially when children fall on an outstretched hand.
  • Children's bones are more flexible and have higher collagen content, making them susceptible to these partial fractures.
  • Though supracondylar fractures of the humerus are the most common complete fractures around the elbow in children (especially 5-10 years), greenstick fractures of the distal radius are more frequent overall.

Greenstick Fracture:

Explanation of Other Options:

Fracture clavicle (Option A): Common in neonates or young children, but not the most frequent across all pediatric age groups.

Supracondylar fracture of humerus (Option C): Most common complete elbow fracture in children, but less common than greenstick fracture of distal radius overall.

Hand fractures (Option D): Less common in young children; more often seen in older children and adolescents.

Key Takeaway:

Greenstick fracture of the distal radius is the most frequent fracture in children overall due to their unique bone physiology.

choices.text: Open injury with loss of physis
Transverse fracture of the metaphysis with longitudinal extension into the physis

questions.text: A 12-year-old boy presents to the emergency department after falling while playing football. He complains of pain and swelling around the distal femur. On X-ray, a fracture line is seen extending through the physis and exiting through the metaphysis, with a triangular metaphyseal fragment seen at the fracture margin. What is the most likely diagnosis?
questions.solution:
Explanation:

The described X-ray finding - a fracture that passes through the physis and into the metaphysis with a triangular metaphyseal fragment - is characteristic of a Salter-Harris type II fracture. The triangular fragment is known as the Thurston-Holland fragment, and when visible on radiographs, it is termed the Thurston-Holland sign.

  • Salter-Harris classification is the most commonly used system to describe physeal injuries in children.
  • Type II is the most common (≈75%) and carries a good prognosis as it spares the epiphysis and thus the joint surface.
  • The Thurston-Holland sign refers to the small metaphyseal triangular fragment attached to the growth plate portion of the fracture.
  • Clinical presentation usually includes localised tenderness over a growth plate, swelling, pain, and difficulty bearing weight or moving the affected limb.
  • Diagnosis is based on clinical suspicion and radiographic imaging.

Explanation of Other Options:

Perichondrial ring injury (Option A): Refers to injury of the fibrous ring surrounding the physis; not the hallmark of Salter-Harris type II.

Open injury with loss of physis (Option C): Not a defining feature of any specific Salter-Harris type; usually seen in severe trauma or grade V injury.

Transverse fracture of metaphysis with longitudinal extension into physis (Option D): Describes an unusual fracture pattern not consistent with standard Salter-Harris classification.

Key Takeaway:

The Thurston-Holland fragment is a pathognomonic radiographic feature of Salter-Harris Type II fracture, the most common physeal injury in children.

Reference: Radiopaedia: Salter-Harris classification - https://radiopaedia.org/articles/salter-harris-classification

choices.text: Closed manipulative reduction and POP application
Breakage of the intact cortex, closed reduction of the fracture and POP application

questions.text: A 6-year-old child falls onto his right side and develops a crack in only the dorsal cortex of the mid region of the radius. The best treatment?
questions.solution:
Explanation:

The X-ray findings and clinical scenario describe a greenstick fracture, which is a unicortical fracture seen exclusively in children due to the increased pliability of their bones and thick periosteum. These fractures typically affect the radius and ulna.

  • Green stick fractures are unicortical fractures of bone seen in children. This occurs due to the thick periosteum in children. Greenstick fractures are commonly seen in the forearm bones.
  • These fractures have to be treated by breaking the intact cortex and reducing the fracture. This breakage of the intact cortex is called osteoclasis. If osteoclasis is not performed, then there is a tendency for the deformity of the fracture to recur when the child grows.

Explanation of Other Options:

TENS nailing (Option A): Used for diaphyseal fractures with complete cortical disruption or in polytrauma cases - not required in greenstick fractures.

Open reduction and plating (Option B): Too invasive for a simple greenstick fracture in a child; reserved for unstable or failed conservative cases.

Closed manipulative reduction and POP (Option C): Incomplete if osteoclasis is not done - the risk of recurrent angulation due to springing back of intact cortex.

Key Takeaway:

Greenstick fractures require breakage of the intact cortex (osteoclasis) to prevent recurrent deformity and ensure proper alignment during healing.

questions.text: A 68-year-old male with a known case of metastatic prostate carcinoma presents with severe pain in the right thigh. X-ray reveals a lytic lesion involving more than two-thirds of the cortical diameter in the proximal femur. He has difficulty weight bearing and severe pain even at rest. Which of the following clinical tools would best help in deciding the need for prophylactic fixation?
questions.solution:
Explanation:

Mirel's scoring system helps determine the risk of pathological fracture in long bones affected by metastatic lesions. It is a validated tool to decide whether prophylactic fixation is required.

  • A score of ≥8 indicates a high risk of fracture and the need for surgical stabilisation.
  • A score of ≤7 is usually managed conservatively or with radiotherapy.
  • Total Score Range: 4-12
  • Intervention Threshold: Score ≥8 → prophylactic fixation recommended

Explanation of Other Options:

DEXA scan (Option A): Used to assess bone mineral density in osteoporosis, not applicable for metastatic bone lesions.

FRAX score (Option B): Used to assess osteoporotic fracture risk, not for pathological fractures due to metastasis.

ASIA score (Option D): Classifies the severity of spinal cord injury, unrelated to bone metastasis or fracture risk.

Key Takeaways:

  • Mirel's score is the standard tool for evaluating fracture risk in metastatic bone disease.
  • Helps guide early prophylactic fixation to prevent nonunion and complications.
  • Radiographic and clinical assessment together form the basis of decision-making.

questions.text: A 78-year-old postmenopausal woman presents with sudden pain in the hip after rising from a chair. There is no history of trauma. X-ray reveals a transverse fracture of the proximal femur. She has a known history of hypertension and is on long-term corticosteroids for polymyalgia rheumatica. What is the most likely underlying cause of her fracture?
questions.solution:
Explanation:

Osteoporosis is the most common cause of pathological fractures, especially in elderly individuals with reduced bone mass. (Other options are ruled out)

  • Even trivial stress can result in fractures.
  • In this case, the absence of significant trauma, long-term steroid use, and age strongly suggests osteoporosis as the underlying pathology.

questions.text: Which of the following structures is fixed first during the reimplantation of an amputated digit?
questions.solution:
Explanation:

The sequence of repair in digit or limb reimplantation follows a structured approach for optimal anatomical and functional recovery. The bone is repaired first to provide a stable scaffold for alignment and fixation.

  • Standard order of repair (Mnemonic: BE FAN of Virender Sehwag):
    • B - Bone: fixed first to establish structural integrity
    • E - Extensor tendons
    • F - Flexor tendons
    • A - Artery: crucial for restoring perfusion
    • N - Nerve: restored for sensory and motor function
    • V - Vein: repaired to ensure venous return
    • S - Skin: closed last

Although vascular repair (artery and vein) is given high priority to ensure tissue survival, bone fixation is done first as it is necessary for accurate positioning and stability of all other structures.

Explanation of Other Options:

Artery (Option B): Vital for limb viability, but repaired after bone and tendon structures are stabilised.

Vein (Option C): Repaired after arterial supply and nerve, to allow venous drainage and reduce congestion.

Nerve (Option D): Restored after vascular supply; delayed repair beyond initial surgery is sometimes acceptable.

questions.text: Which Salter-Harris type of physeal injury does not displace the growth plate but damages it by direct compression?
questions.solution:
Explanation:

Salter-Harris Type V is a crush injury to the physis, where there is no displacement of the growth plate but severe damage due to axial compression. It often goes undiagnosed initially as the injury may not be evident on early X-rays, but later results in growth arrest and deformity due to physeal necrosis.

  • There are many helpful mnemonics to help remember this classification system, and consequently, they are in order of prognosis from best to worst.

S: slipped physis (type I)

A: above physis (type II)

L: lower to physis (type III)

T: through or transverse or together physis (type IV)

ER: Erasure of the physis (type V)

Explanation of Other Options:

Type I (Option A): Transverse fracture through physis; physis slips off epiphysis.

Type IV (Option B): Fracture through metaphysis, physis, and epiphysis; disrupts growth plate continuity.

Type II (Option C): Fracture through physis and metaphysis; most common type.

Reference: Radiopaedia: Salter-Harris classification (https://radiopaedia.org/articles/salter-harris-classification?lang=us)

questions.text: According to the Salter-Harris classification, which type of physeal fracture is shown on this x-ray (lateral view) of the right ankle?
questions.solution:
Explanation:

This x-ray demonstrates a fracture through the posterior aspect of the tibial metaphysis, extending to the growth plate, which appears disrupted. The triangular metaphyseal fragment is known as the Thurston-Holland fragment, which indicates that a type 2 Salter-Harris fracture has occurred.

  • Type II is by far the most common and has a good prognosis.
  • It is characterised by a fracture through the growth plate and metaphysis, sparing the epiphysis.
  • The metaphyseal fragment seen radiographically confirms the diagnosis.

Explanation of Other Options:

Type I (Option A): Straight through the physis; no bone fragment involved.

Type III (Option C): Through physis and epiphysis; intra-articular fracture.

Type IV (Option D): Through metaphysis, physis, and epiphysis; involves all three layers.

questions.text: Which of the following bones is the most commonly fractured in adults?
questions.solution:
Explanation:

The most common fracture overall is - clavicle > distal end of radius

  • Age-wise
    • The most common fracture at birth is - clavicle
    • The most common fracture in children is - greenstick fracture of the forearm bones.
  • The midshaft of the clavicle is especially prone to fracture due to its subcutaneous position and exposure to direct or transmitted forces.
  • In adults, high-energy trauma (e.g., road traffic accidents or falls onto the shoulder) frequently leads to clavicular fractures.

Explanation of Other Options:

Distal forearm (Option A): Common in the elderly (especially due to osteoporosis), but clavicle remains most common overall in adults.

Humerus (Option B): More common in elderly females due to falls, but not the most common overall.

Carpals (Option D): Includes scaphoid fractures; common in young adults, but lower overall incidence compared to clavicle fractures.

choices.text: Surgical repair of the flexor tendon

questions.text: A 30-year-old man is involved in a street fight and presents with pain and deformity of his left middle finger. He is unable to extend the tip of the finger. The X-ray is negative for any fracture. Examination reveals a flexion deformity of the distal phalanx at the DIP joint. What is the most appropriate next step in management?
questions.solution:
Explanation:

The clinical presentation and deformity described are consistent with mallet finger, which is caused by disruption or rupture of the terminal extensor tendon at the distal interphalangeal (DIP) joint. This leads to the characteristic inability to extend the distal phalanx actively, with the finger resting in flexion.

  • Most common cause: Sudden forced flexion of an extended finger tip (e.g., during ball-catching injuries or tucking bedsheets).
  • Radiographs may be normal or show a small avulsion fragment from the dorsal base of the distal phalanx.
  • Management:
    • Non-operative: Extension splinting of the DIP joint continuously for 6-8 weeks.
    • Surgery is reserved for volar subluxation, large avulsion fragments, chronic cases, or failed conservative treatment.

Explanation of Other Options:

Buddy strapping (Option A): Used for collateral ligament injuries or phalangeal shaft fractures, not for DIP injuries.

Splint in hyperflexion (Option C): Not indicated; would worsen extensor tendon deformity.

Surgical repair of the flexor tendon (Option D): Incorrect, as the flexor tendon is not involved in the mallet finger.

choices.text: Repeat splinting of the distal interphalangeal joint in extension
Splinting of the distal and proximal interphalangeal joints in extension
Fusion of the distal interphalangeal joint

questions.text: A 42-year-old sustains a left finger injury while attempting to catch a baseball for his son. He presents with left long finger pain and an inability to extend his middle finger at the distal interphalangeal joint. A radiograph after closed reduction and splinting is shown in the figure. What is the best course of treatment?
questions.solution:
Explanation:

The presence of a large intra-articular bony avulsion fragment and persistent volar subluxation of the distal phalanx, despite splinting, confirms that this is a bony mallet injury requiring surgical intervention.

  • Mallet finger results from disruption of the terminal extensor tendon at the DIP joint, sometimes with a bony avulsion.
  • Non-operative management is sufficient in most uncomplicated cases.
  • Surgical indications include:
    • Large bony avulsion
    • Persistent volar subluxation of the distal phalanx despite extension splinting
  • In this case, due to persistent subluxation seen post-splinting, open or percutaneous reduction and pinning are necessary.

Explanation of Other Options:

Repeat splinting (Option B): Already attempted; failed due to persistent subluxation.

Splinting both DIP and PIP (Option C): Not standard; DIP splinting alone is standard in uncomplicated mallet finger.

Fusion of DIP joint (Option D): Last-resort option for chronic or failed cases, not suitable for a young adult.

questions.text: A 55-year-old electrician presents after falling due to an electric shock. He complains of severe shoulder pain and inability to abduct or externally rotate his left upper limb. On examination, his arm is adducted and internally rotated. What is the most likely diagnosis?
questions.solution:
Explanation:

Posterior shoulder dislocation is classically associated with seizures, electric shock, or high-energy trauma (Triple E Syndrome) and presents with internal rotation and adduction of the shoulder.

  • The mechanism involves forceful contraction of the internal rotators, leading to posterior displacement of the humeral head.
  • Often missed on standard AP view → confirm with axillary or scapular Y view.

Explanation of Other Options:

Anterior dislocation (Option A): The most common type of shoulder dislocation. Presents with the arm abducted and externally rotated, often with a visible deformity. Not associated with electric shock or seizures.

Clavicle fracture (Option B): Typically results from a fall on an outstretched hand or direct trauma to the shoulder. Presents with localised tenderness, swelling, and possibly visible deformity over the clavicle, but does not lead to global limitation of shoulder rotation.

Luxatio erecta (Option D): Inferior dislocation of the shoulder. The arm is held in a fixed overhead position (hyperabduction). Rare and distinctly different from the adducted/internally rotated posture seen in posterior dislocation.

questions.text: A neonate diagnosed with developmental dysplasia of the hip (DDH) is managed with the splint shown in the image below. Identify the splint.
questions.solution:
Explanation:

Von Rosen splint is an H-shaped, malleable passive positioning device used in infants with developmental dysplasia of the hip (DDH). It maintains the hips in flexion and abduction, the optimal position for concentric reduction of the femoral head within the acetabulum.

  • Allows minimal movement, unlike the Pavlik harness, which is dynamic.
  • Should be avoided in extreme positions to prevent avascular necrosis.
  • Used as an alternative when the Pavlik harness is contraindicated or fails.

Explanation of Other Options:

Pavlik harness (Option B): Dynamic harness used in DDH; maintains hip in flexion and abduction but allows movement. Preferred initial treatment for DDH in infants under 6 months.

Dennis Brown splint (Option C): Used in clubfoot treatment; maintains foot abduction post-correction. Not used for DDH.

Aeroplane splint (Option D): Used for shoulder abduction in brachial plexus injuries or after axillary burns; unrelated to hip pathology.

questions.text: A 10-year-old boy is brought by his parents due to painless swelling over both knees for the past few weeks. There is no history of trauma or fever. On examination, there is bilateral knee effusion with preserved joint mobility and no signs of inflammation. On reviewing the child's history, he was treated in infancy for skin lesions and nasal discharge. What is the most probable diagnosis?
questions.solution:
Explanation:

Clutton's joints are painless, symmetrical, non-inflammatory effusions seen primarily in the knees of children with late congenital syphilis.

  • It is a manifestation of late congenital syphilis, not early or tertiary forms.
  • Often subclinical and discovered incidentally, but classical in congenital syphilis cases.

Explanation of Other Options:

Early congenital syphilis (Option A): Presents before 2 years with features like snuffles, rash, and skeletal lesions, but not Clutton's joints.

Tertiary syphilis (Option C): Occurs in acquired syphilis many years later in life and may present with gummas and neurological signs.

questions.text: A 30-year-old male presents to the emergency department after a fall from a ladder. He complains of severe pain and swelling in his right thigh. On examination, there is significant tenderness and visible deformity over the mid-thigh. Passive manipulation elicits a grating sensation, and the limb shows movement at a point where there is no joint. What is the most pathognomonic sign confirming the diagnosis of a fracture?
questions.solution:
Explanation:

Abnormal mobility at a site where no joint exists is pathognomonic of a bone fracture. It indicates complete disruption of bone continuity.

  • Crepitus and abnormal mobility are late signs and should be elicited gently.
  • Early management should prioritise immobilisation to prevent neurovascular compromise.

Explanation of Other Options:

Tenderness (Option A): Common in many injuries, including soft tissue trauma; not pathognomonic.

Swelling (Option B): Non-specific; may be seen in infections, sprains, or contusions.

Crepitus (Option D): A suggestive but not pathognomonic sign; also seen in infections or joint effusions.

questions.text: Which of the following is not a component of crush syndrome?
questions.solution:
Explanation:

Bleeding diathesis is not a feature of crush syndrome. The syndrome results from prolonged muscle compression and ischemia, followed by reperfusion, leading to the systemic release of toxic muscle breakdown products such as myoglobin, potassium, and phosphate.

Definition:

Crush syndrome is a systemic manifestation of severe traumatic muscle injury resulting from prolonged compression. It involves reperfusion injury when crushed tissues are suddenly revascularized.

Aetiology:

  • Prolonged limb compression: e.g. earthquake, building collapse, road traffic accidents (RTA) with entrapment.
  • Battlefield injuries or industrial accidents.

Pathophysiology:

  • Ischemic muscle undergoes necrosis during prolonged compression.
  • Upon reperfusion, toxic metabolites (e.g., myoglobin, potassium, phosphate, uric acid) enter the systemic circulation.
  • Myoglobin precipitates in renal tubules, leading to acute tubular necrosis and renal failure.
  • Electrolyte abnormalities (hyperkalemia, hypocalcemia) contribute to cardiac arrhythmias and systemic complications.

Clinical Features:

  • Hypovolemic or distributive shock
  • Myoglobinuria (dark brown urine)
  • Acute renal failure due to acute tubular necrosis
  • Local signs: tense, swollen, painful muscles
  • Systemic signs: hyperkalemia, metabolic acidosis

Investigations:

  • Serum electrolytes: ↑ K+, ↑ phosphate, ↓ Ca²+
  • Serum creatinine kinase (CK): markedly elevated
  • Urinalysis: positive for myoglobin
  • Renal function tests: elevated urea and creatinine
  • ECG: changes due to hyperkalemia (e.g., peaked T waves)

Management:

  • Early and aggressive fluid resuscitation to maintain renal perfusion
  • Mannitol with alkaline diuresis to prevent pigment nephropathy
  • Calcium gluconate for cardioprotection in hyperkalemia
  • Dialysis if acute renal failure develops
  • Surgical decompression (fasciotomy) if compartment syndrome coexists

Explanation of Other Options:

Myoglobinuria (Option A): Classic feature caused by rhabdomyolysis, leading to pigment-induced renal injury.

Shock (Option B): Common due to third-space fluid loss, muscle necrosis, and systemic inflammation.

Acute tubular necrosis (Option C): Due to direct nephrotoxicity of myoglobin.

questions.text: A 25-year-old male presents to the emergency department after a road traffic accident with pain, swelling, and deformity over the mid-shaft of the femur. X-ray confirms a transverse fracture. He undergoes conservative management with splinting. Within the first few hours, local bleeding is noted at the site. What is the first stage in the process of fracture healing in this patient?
questions.solution:
Explanation:

Hematoma formation is the first stage of fracture healing, initiating the inflammatory cascade required for new bone formation.

Definition:

Fracture healing is the process through which bone regenerates and restores its structure and function after trauma.

Etiology:

Common causes include:

  • High-energy trauma (e.g., RTA)
  • Falls
  • Sports injuries
  • Pathological fractures due to weakened bone

3. Pathophysiology (Stages of Secondary Bone Healing):

Clinical Features:

  • Pain, swelling, deformity, and tenderness at the site
  • Inability to bear weight or use the limb
  • Crepitus or abnormal mobility in displaced fractures

Investigations:

  • X-ray: Initial and follow-up to assess healing
  • CT scan: For complex or intra-articular fractures
  • Bone scan/MRI: If delayed union is suspected

Management:

  • Conservative: Immobilisation with splints/casts
  • Surgical: Internal fixation for unstable or displaced fractures
  • Supportive: Analgesia, elevation, physiotherapy
  • Monitoring: Assess for union, delayed union, or non-union

Explanation of Other Options:

Stage of bleeding (Option A): Bleeding leads to hematoma but is not a distinct stage of healing.

Stage of enchondral calcification (Option B): Part of hard callus formation, not the initial phase.

Stage of remodelling (Option D): The final stage involves replacement of woven bone by lamellar bone.

questions.text: All of the following are causes of non-union in fracture healing except:
questions.solution:
Explanation:

Osteoporosis does not interfere with the biological process of fracture healing, though it predisposes to fracture by weakening the bone. In contrast, infection, tumour metastasis, and metabolic bone diseases like osteomalacia impair the healing process and are well-established causes of non-union.

Definition:

Non-union is defined as the failure of a fracture to unite within 9 months of injury and with no visible progression of healing over 3 months.

  • The causes of nonunion are given below.

Pathophysiology:

Failure to bridge the fracture gap due to impaired osteogenesis or mechanical instability. The biological repair cascade is interrupted at the callus formation or remodelling stages.

Clinical Features:

  • Persistent pain and tenderness at the fracture site
  • No radiographic signs of union after the expected healing time
  • Sometimes painless "pseudoarthrosis" (mobile non-union)
  • ± Deformity or instability at the fracture site

Investigation:

  • X-ray: Persistent fracture line, sclerosis of fracture ends
  • MRI/CT: Assess callus formation, vascularity, and occult pathology
  • Lab tests: If infection suspected (CRP, ESR, WBC), rule out metabolic bone disease

Management:

  • Mechanical stabilisation: Internal fixation or revision surgery
  • Biological stimulation: Bone grafts, BMPs
  • Infection control: If septic non-union
  • Treatment of underlying cause: Vitamin D for osteomalacia, chemo/radiation for metastasis

choices.text: Log roll the patient onto a stretcher
Turn the patient onto the side

questions.text: A 32-year-old male is brought to the emergency department following a high-velocity road traffic accident. He is unconscious with visible injuries to the head and lower limbs. As part of the immediate pre-hospital management, which of the following actions is contraindicated during the initial handling?
questions.solution:
Explanation:

Turning the patient to the side is not a part of the ATLS primary survey and is contraindicated during the initial management of trauma cases, as it risks exacerbating spinal injuries.

Definition:

The Advanced Trauma Life Support (ATLS) protocol is a structured approach to managing trauma, focusing on the rapid identification and management of life-threatening injuries, particularly in the first "golden hour."

Aetiology:

Trauma from road traffic accidents, falls, and blunt force can cause spinal instability or multisystem injuries requiring strict immobilisation protocols during early handling.

Pathophysiology:

Improper handling of trauma victims may worsen spinal cord injuries. Unnecessary movement-such as turning the patient to the side-can compromise airway protection or cause secondary neurological deterioration.

Clinical Features:

  • Common presentations: altered consciousness, bleeding, suspected fractures
  • Vital focus during initial management: Airway, Breathing, Circulation, Disability, Exposure (ABCDE)

Investigation:

  • Initial adjuncts: Pulse oximetry, capnography, ECG, urinary catheter, blood gases, imaging (X-rays, FAST, CT)
  • Immobilisation is crucial until spinal injury is ruled out

Management:

  • Follow ATLS protocol strictly:
    • A: Secure airway with cervical spine protection
    • B: Ensure adequate ventilation
    • C: Control haemorrhage and maintain perfusion
    • D: Assess neurological status with GCS
    • E: Fully expose the patient while preventing hypothermia
  • Use of:
    • Hard backboard/stretchers
    • Cervical collars and spinal immobilisation devices
    • Log roll manoeuvre (only when spinal protection is ensured and clinically indicated)

Explanation of Other Options:

Log roll the patient onto a stretcher (Option A): Permitted and standard technique when spinal precautions are taken, mainly used to examine the back or move the patient carefully.

Use a hardback stretcher (Option B): Correct practice during transport of trauma patients to maintain spinal alignment.

Apply a collar (Option D): Essential step to immobilise the cervical spine and prevent secondary spinal injury.

Key Takeaways:

questions.text: A 7-year-old child presented with elbow stiffness one month after sustaining a supracondylar fracture of the humerus that was treated by a local bone setter with oil massage and tight bandaging. On examination, there is a limited range of motion of the elbow without pain. X-ray shows early calcification anterior to the humerus, suggestive of immature myositis ossificans. What is the most appropriate next step in management?
questions.solution:
Explanation:

Immature myositis ossificans should be treated conservatively with rest and NSAIDs. Surgery is delayed until the lesion matures.

Definition:

Myositis ossificans is a benign condition characterised by heterotopic bone formation within soft tissue, often around joints, following trauma or excessive manipulation.

Etiology:

  • Common after trauma or repeated massage/manipulation, especially by bone setters
  • Occurs around the elbow, hip, or thigh
  • Most commonly affects the brachialis muscle in upper limb injuries

Pathophysiology:

  • It involves intramuscular haemorrhage leading to fibroblastic activity and subsequent bone formation in muscle tissue
  • Bone formation is progressive and can lead to mechanical joint stiffness

Clinical Features:

  • History of trauma or massage
  • Swelling, stiffness of the joint, reduced range of motion
  • Pain may or may not be present
  • X-ray shows calcification adjacent to bone (usually anterior to the humerus)

Investigation:

  • X-ray: Initially normal; by 2-3 weeks shows calcific mass with a radiolucent rim
  • CT/MRI: Used to differentiate from neoplasms if needed
  • Bone scan: Increased uptake in active lesions
  • No need for biopsy unless features are atypical or rapidly progressive

Management:

Explanation of Other Options:

Aggressive physiotherapy (Option A): Contraindicated in the immature stage; can worsen ossification.

Plan excision of myositic mass (Option B): Done only after maturation of lesion to prevent recurrence.

Biopsy to rule out malignancy (Option C): Not routinely required unless clinical or radiological suspicion of tumour (e.g., osteosarcoma).

questions.text: A 24-year-old male presents 48 hours after sustaining a closed femoral shaft fracture in a road traffic accident. He now complains of breathlessness, confusion, and a non-blanching petechial rash over his upper chest. On examination, pulse rate is 118 bpm, and SpO2 is 88% on room air. Based on Gurd's criteria for fat embolism syndrome, which of the following is not included among the major criteria?
questions.solution:
Explanation:

Tachycardia is part of Gurd's minor criteria. Major criteria include petechial rash, cerebral involvement, and respiratory distress.

Definition

Fat Embolism Syndrome (FES) is a serious complication of long bone fractures, particularly the femur, characterised by systemic dissemination of fat droplets, leading to multiorgan involvement.

Aetiology

  • Typically follows fractures of long bones (femur, pelvis)
  • Fat globules enter circulation from the disrupted marrow
  • Can lodge in the pulmonary and systemic microvasculature

Gurd's Diagnostic Criteria

Clinical Features

  • Onset typically within 24-72 hours post-trauma
  • Classic triad:
    1. Respiratory symptoms: dyspnea, hypoxia, ARDS
    2. Neurological symptoms: confusion, agitation, coma
    3. Petechial rash: upper body, axillae, conjunctiva

Investigations

  • ABG: Hypoxia (PaO2 <60 mmHg)
  • Chest X-ray: "snowstorm" appearance
  • Urine/sputum: fat globules
  • Fundoscopy: retinal haemorrhages

Management

  • Supportive care: oxygen, mechanical ventilation if needed
  • Early fracture stabilisation is preventive
  • The role of steroids is controversial
  • No role for anticoagulants

Explanation of Other Options:

Petechial rashes (Option A): Major criterion; due to capillary occlusion by fat.

Cerebral symptoms (Option B): Major criterion; caused by cerebral hypoxia or fat microemboli.

Respiratory distress (Option D): Major criterion; reflects fat embolism in pulmonary circulation.

choices.text: POP, when dipped in water, turns into gypsum
Warm water quickens the setting of POP
Plaster of Paris slabs are preferred over casts in the presence of swelling

questions.text: All are true regarding plaster of Paris (POP) application except:
questions.solution:
Explanation:

POP is composed of calcium sulphate hemihydrate, not calcium phosphate.

  • Chemical Nature:
    • Plaster of Paris is calcium sulphate hemihydrate (CaSO4·½H2O).
    • It is derived by heating gypsum (CaSO4·2H2O) to remove water.
  • Setting Reaction:
    • On adding water, POP rehydrates to form gypsum (CaSO4·2H2O).
    • This reaction is exothermic and results in hardening.
  • Setting Time Modifiers:
    • Warm water accelerates the setting reaction.
    • Cold water slows the setting.
  • Application Preference:
    • In cases with significant swelling, POP slabs are preferred over full casts to accommodate expansion and reduce the risk of compartment syndrome.

Explanation of Other Options:

POP, when dipped in water, turns into gypsum (Option B): True. This hydration reaction forms a hard, supportive cast.

Warm water quickens the setting of POP (Option C): True. Heat accelerates the setting process.

Plaster of Paris slabs are preferred over casts in the presence of swelling (Option D): True. Slabs are semi-rigid and allow for soft tissue expansion, reducing the risk of complications.

choices.text: Shiny skin and swelling after the removal of the cast

questions.text: A 15-year-old boy underwent corrective spinal surgery for adolescent idiopathic scoliosis and was placed in a spica cast. Two days postoperatively, he complains of persistent epigastric pain and multiple episodes of non-bilious vomiting. On examination, his abdomen is distended and tympanic, but there is no rebound tenderness or guarding. What is the most likely diagnosis?
questions.solution:
Explanation:

The correct answer is A because cast syndrome, also known as superior mesenteric artery (SMA) syndrome, presents with abdominal pain and vomiting due to duodenal compression.

Definition

Cast syndrome (SMA syndrome) is a rare but serious postoperative complication that occurs when the third part of the duodenum is compressed between the abdominal aorta and the superior mesenteric artery, typically following spinal surgery and immobilisation in a body cast.

Aetiology

  • Most common after scoliosis correction in adolescents
  • Caused by the narrowing of the angle between the aorta and the SMA
  • Factors: spinal surgery, excessive weight loss, prone positioning

Pathophysiology

  • Loss of retroperitoneal fat → SMA becomes more acute in angulation
  • Duodenum gets compressed between the SMA and the aorta → obstruction
  • Delayed gastric emptying and duodenal stasis ensue

Clinical Features

  • Nausea, persistent vomiting, abdominal distension
  • Epigastric pain, especially after meals
  • Weight loss, early satiety

Investigation

  • CT angiography or Upper GI contrast study → shows duodenal compression
  • Fluoroscopy: useful to visualise the aortomesenteric angle
  • Endoscopy to rule out mechanical obstruction

Management

  • Initial: NG decompression, electrolyte correction, nutritional support
  • Prone or left lateral positioning
  • Severe cases: Duodenojejunostomy

Explanation of Other Options:

Pain on passive stretch (Option B): Suggestive of compartment syndrome, not cast syndrome.

Shiny skin and swelling after removal of cast (Option C): Describes rebound oedema after prolonged cast immobilisation, not SMA syndrome.

Osteoporosis due to disuse (Option D): A long-term complication of immobilisation, not an acute surgical complication.

questions.text: Myodesis is contraindicated in amputations done for which condition?
questions.solution:
Explanation:

Myodesis is contraindicated in ischemic limbs because suturing muscle directly to bone in a poorly perfused area may further compromise blood supply and lead to necrosis.

  • Myodesis involves anchoring the cut end of the muscle to bone or periosteum.
  • It provides a more stable and functional stump than myoplasty, which attaches muscle to muscle.
  • However, in ischemic conditions like peripheral vascular disease, myodesis is avoided to prevent further compromise of already marginal tissue perfusion.
  • Myoplasty is preferred in such scenarios as it is less likely to impair the remaining vascular supply.

Explanation of Other Options:

Infections (Option B): Not an absolute contraindication if infection is adequately controlled.

Tumours (Option C): Myodesis may be done if the vascular supply is intact and oncologic clearance permits.

Insensate limb (Option D): Sensory loss does not directly contraindicate myodesis.

questions.text: In closed amputations, which of the following structures is intentionally cut shorter than the level of amputation?
questions.solution:
Explanation:

Nerves are cut shorter than other structures during closed amputations to minimise the risk of painful neuroma formation.

  • Neuroma formation occurs if nerves are cut at the same level as the stump end and are not allowed to retract into deep tissue.
  • This surgical principle is emphasised during proper wound preparation to avoid post-amputation pain.
